channel.title: Mariano Gappa's Blog
channel.description: Recent content on Mariano Gappa's Blog

item.title: Making Games in Go: 3 Months Without LLMs vs 3 Days With LLMs!
item.description: I built two classic Argentinian card games in Go: one took 3 months without LLMs, the other just 3 days with them — and a step-by-step guide to make your own game.

item.title: Mind the gap!
item.description: A hand on the fire instantly teaches danger, but alcoholism’s harm unfolds slowly. This latter indirection, or gap in feedback, is bridged with narratives: stories we adopt, often without noticing. We underestimate how deeply the narratives we choose affect us. Mind the gap!

item.title: How We Handle Billion-Row ClickHouse Inserts With UUID Range Bucketing
item.description: How we solved OOM issues in ClickHouse using a simple UUID-range bucketing algorithm called InsertSplitter.

item.title: A Joyful Tale of Golang Memory Profiling at CloudQuery
item.description: A step-by-step approach on resolving memory issues I experienced at work, leading to an 84% reduction in memory usage with no adverse impacts on the product.

item.title: On being parasitical
item.description: An exploration of the concept of being parasitical, examining moral considerations, and ultimately questioning where individuals draw the line in accepting or rejecting such behavior.

item.title: Real-life indirection is the root of all evil (and AI agents can fix it)
item.description: The blogpost explores how the evil downsides of indirection, a programming principle that can be conceptualised in real life, can (and invariably will?) be challenged by the latest AI developments.

item.description: The blogpost explores how the evil downsides of indirection, a programming principle that can be conceptualised in real life, can (and invariably will?) be challenged by the latest AI developments.

item.title: Building Crypto Predictions Tracker: architecture and challenges
item.description: A summary of my experience building a Go-based project that tracks cryptocurrency predictions on social media and evaluates their accuracy using publicly available market data.

item.title: Cryptocurrency influencers are preying on millennials who found salvation in crypto
item.description: Blogpost on past & present of investing, focusing on the problem of the difficulty of finding reputable advice on cryptocurrency investments. Also presenting an engine I created to keep a track-record for cryptocurrency influencers, called the Crypto Predictions Tracker.

item.title: 10 Gotchas for building a universal crypto candlestick iterator in Go
item.description: My journey building a universal crypto candlestick iterator in Go, with tips for all the challenges you’ll face working with crypto exchanges’ APIs.

item.title: Running Golang on the browser with WebAssembly and TinyGo
item.description: This is the story of how I managed to expose my Golang chess backend project cheesse as a WebAssembly binary, compiled using TinyGo, so JavaScript could use it, without needing a server.

item.title: Let's build a SQL parser in Go!
item.description: This article aims to be the simplest introduction to constructing an LL(1) parser in Go, in this case for parsing SQL queries. It assumes minimal programming competence (functions, structs, ifs and for-loops).

item.title: We saved $50k/y with a tiny Go microservice coded in a Hackathon
item.description: In the past few weeks we’ve rolled out a Go microservice called ‘KIB’ to production, which reduced a huge portion of the infrastructure necessary for Movio’s main product, saving considerable AWS bills & maintenance, significantly simplified our architecture and made our product 80% faster on average. We wrote KIB on a Hackathon.

item.title: How we improved our workflow by piping sql
item.description: I’ve written a blogpost for Movio about two Go CLI tools we’ve created, sql and chart, to improve our data tinkering workflow

item.title: Ostinato: a chess engine written in Scala that runs on the browser, Docker and the REPL
item.description: A chess engine that solves several use-cases that there are no good free online sources for, and a good candidate for AI research or for a backend for chess sites.

item.title: Making the move from Scala to Go, and why we’re not going back
item.description: I’ve written a blogpost for Movio about our squad’s decision to migrate part of our Scala codebase to Go.

item.title: Diffing streams on the terminal
item.description: In this blogpost, I describe the most popular tools currently used to diff streams on the terminal, their differences and limitations. Then I introduce a new tool I’ve developed, sd, to address some of these limitations.

item.title: jira-cli: a lightweight bash script for easily querying JIRA
item.description: Quick introduction to a bash-based tool for ops and devs to do JIRA-related read-only tasks that is easy to install, configure and use.

item.title: Fixing syntax highlighting issues in Sublime Text 3
item.description: A straightforward guide to fixing syntax highlighting issues in Sublime Text 3 based on an actual issue I found.

item.title: About
item.description:
I’m a software engineer and studio mixer based in Dubai, UAE.

All views, posts and opinions shared on this blog and on my tweets are my own.

item.title: Projects
item.description:
Ostinato

https://github.com/marianogappa/ostinato
A chess library that runs on the server (Scala) and on the browser (ScalaJS). Try the notation converter here

Cheesse

https://github.com/marianogappa/cheesse
Package, server, cli tool and WebAssembly binary for chess use cases.

Truco

https://github.com/marianogappa/truco

Truco argentino implementation, featuring:

  • websocket-based client/server architecture
  • example terminal-based frontend
  • example React-based frontend, and a simple, documented interface for making your own frontend
  • example bot, and a simple, documented interface for making your own
